title: Question 5

children: A 42-year-old man with HIV infection seeks advice regarding HIV transmission risk. He is in a committed, monogamous relationship, and his husband is HIV negative (confirmed by fourth generation HIV testing 2 days ago). His HIV infection has been well-controlled for 10 years. His only medication is a fixed, co-formulated regimen of tenofovir alafenamide, emtricitabine, and bictegravir once daily.
Laboratory studies 1 week ago showed an undetectable HIV-1 quantitative RNA, which remains the same from 6 months and 1 year ago. The last CD4 cell count was 650/µL.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management to prevent HIV transmission?

text.__html: Consistent condom use with each episode of sex
Daily HIV pre-exposure prophylaxis for the partner
On-demand HIV pre-exposure prophylaxis for the partner

children: The risk of HIV transmission is essentially zero in patients who have a sustained, undetectable viral load for at least 6 months (Undetectable = Untransmittable), so monogamous, serodifferent partners do not require further HIV prevention measures.
No additional prevention strategy is necessary (

). Persons with HIV infection who have at least 6 months of sustained viral suppression have effectively no risk of sexually transmitting HIV to HIV-negative partners. A large multicenter, observational study of HIV serodiscordant couples (including same-sex and heterosexual couples) showed no transmissions of HIV during condomless sex from effectively treated HIV-positive to HIV-negative partners. Several other studies have similarly shown that HIV-positive persons with sustained viral suppression do not transmit HIV to their sexual partners. This is described as “Undetectable = Untransmittable” (U = U), which was endorsed by the CDC in 2017. The most important factor is that the HIV-positive partner is consistently taking antiretroviral therapy (ART) and achieves viral suppression, maintaining an undetectable viral load for at least 6 months. U = U has been particularly endorsed to minimize stigma around HIV, and it is encouraged that physicians involved in the care of persons with HIV share this important update with their patients.
Condom use is unlikely to provide further HIV prevention in this committed, monogamous relationship considering the HIV-positive partner's sustained viral suppression (

This patient's risk for transmitting HIV to his partner is effectively zero. HIV pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) is an effective tool for HIV prevention and is often recommended for HIV-negative partners in serodiscordant relationships to prevent HIV acquisition from the HIV-positive partner. However, PrEP is most beneficial when the HIV-positive partner is not taking ART or does not have sustained viral suppression. objective.__html: Manage HIV transmission risk between serodiscordant partners.

references: Rodger AJ, Cambiano V, Bruun T, et al; PARTNER Study Group. Sexual activity without condoms and risk of HIV transmission in serodifferent couples when the HIV-positive partner is using suppressive antiretroviral therapy. JAMA. 2016;316:171-81.
